Posts.Content: May 7, 2015 10:01PM kebab wrote: I have a little wallet card for my port. The first couple of times, I had it in my hand to show as I went through and they were completely uninterested in looking at it. I don't even bother anymore and my port never makes it beep. I wear headscarves and they always give me "special" treatment for that. They ask if I'm willing to remove it and I say no. Then either they pat it down themselves (they always call over a woman to do that part) or they ask me to pat it down myself while they watch, and then they swab my hands. No biggie. Wear your hat. If they ask you to remove it, feel confident about saying "no thank you". They'll figure out a way to make sure you're not a security risk without making you go bald through the airport. :) The only other bit of advice I have from my onc is to get up and walk/move at least once an hour during the flight (don't know how long your flight is). So many of the meds we're on can cause cramping and/or clots, so move when you are able. Have a great time!

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2012 05:29PM kebab wrote: I am right there with you!¬† My fiance is the love of my life. We have spent the last year jumping through immigration hoops so we can be married and live our lives together.¬† But now there are immigration issues related to my diagnosis (nothing major, just setbacks/delays) and those thoughts start to creep in -- maybe this is fate trying to tell me something; maybe it's for the best; maybe he won't like a life with me being sick. It's hard, isn't it? For me, I know it's stemming from the fact that I absolutely hate putting my family and loved ones through this, and maybe if I can "save" him from all of it by pushing him away, that's better, right?¬† Wrong. I know it. You probably know it deep down too. I'm here for a good time, not a long time. I need to live every moment I have to the fullest and be as happy as I can be. So if he's still willing to have me, I think that has to be good enough for me.¬† Why not just talk to him and see where it goes? Let him know your fears and your concerns. Make sure he knows what kind of ride he might be in for.¬† If he understands and still wants to be with you, then go with it, be happy!¬† That's my 2 cents anyway...

Posts.Content: kebab wrote: Hi. I hope you don't mind me crashing the party here, but I thought I should introduce myself instead of just lurking in the shadows. My cancer story: Diagnosed at stage IIb in 2008 at age 38 after finding a lump myself. Lumpectomy, chemo, radiation, started on tamoxifen, but only stayed on 2-1/2 years. 6 months after stopping, last fall, I noticed some nodes in my neck that were "swelling". Had biopsies and CT scan done that came back clear. My onc. was checking the nodes every 6 weeks and kept telling me they were nothing to worry about.¬† February was time for my yearly "once-over" workup, so he added another CT scan. This time it showed some "problems". I have mets in the nodes in my neck and sternum area, plus a bone scan showed mets in my spine and hips.¬† Just started last week on Zoladex (since I'm still premenopausal) and pamidronate injections. My oldest sister was diagnosed in September 2009 and passed away in June 2010 (way too fast!). At that time, I was offered genetic testing, and I'm BRCA2 positive too. My story otherwise: I have 2 terrific kiddos, ages 6 and 9, and I'm engaged to a great guy (who is, understandably, a bit shell-shocked, but still great).¬† I work full-time from my home. Currently in Ontario, but since my fiance lives in the US, we were (are?) planning to move there and get married... Everything seems like it's been cartwheeling out of control this past week, but having found you all here and spent some time browsing around, I'm feeling more calm already. I hate that we're all here, but so very glad to have found you.¬† Stay-at-home mom to 13-yo daughter and 11-yo son. stage iv, node and bone mets; 03/2013 liver mets; 05/2016 brain mets; hospice care. Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2014 08:49AM kebab wrote: Hugs to you, my friend.¬† I don't know anything about skin mets and I am praying hard that this turns out to be something much easier, like an infection.¬† As for dealing... I had a really hard time when I was dx'd with liver mets last year. Like you, I had sort of found my groove with living with bone mets and then, wham, something new. But, do you remember those very first weeks/months after your bone mets dx? When it felt like the world was caving in and life was over? And then you got a treatment plan in place and things started to normalize, right? That's how it will be this time too, if it turns out to be skin mets. It's going to be scary and crazy for a little bit until you get treatment in place and find your new groove. And you WILL find your new groove, just like you did after the bone mets were found. Try to breathe. One breath in, one breath out, and repeat. That's all you have to do for right now. Wait for the biopsy results before you get to a full-on panic -- otherwise you might be wasting precious otherwise-happy moments filled up with worry for something that's no more than an infected pimple.¬† More hugs. Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2014 10:53AM kebab wrote: I have had some ups and downs with Xeloda, but since Friday, when I found out that it has completely annihilated all the mets in my liver, I am a HUGE fan! :) I am about to start cycle #11 and honestly, it's not bad at all.¬† The first couple of cycles I had a weird metallic taste and nothing really tasted "good", but that wasn't a problem for very long. Now, after 10 cycles I have red, hot, dry, sore hands and feet pretty much all the time. Days 12-14 of the cycle, I have some trouble walking because my feet are so painful, but as soon as I start the 7 day break, I get relief almost immediately. That is the worst of the s/e's for me. No nausea or tummy troubles. I'm tired and need a nap most days, but nothing unmanageable. But, as I said, my liver mets are completely gone, and the mets in my bones and lymph nodes are smaller than they were at my last scan in October. The side effects are well worth the good work Xeloda is doing on the cancer. I hope that if you have to start Xeloda, it will be great for you too.

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2013 12:04PM kebab wrote: As a mother of an 11-1/2-year-old girl, I think that being immensely irritated by siblings in general is par for the course for any 12-year-old girl. At home, I let my daughter take some time for herself, doing something away from her brother (who is usually the source of her irritation) and just get some space. When they are at school, there's nothing I can do. I just tell her she is going to have people throughout her life who get on her nerves and make her crazy. She needs to start now to figure out how to deal with it on her own when I'm not there and she can't get some space. My nephew, who used to live with us, has Down Syndrome. He's 30, but operates at roughly at 7-year-old level and, though not autistic, will repeat the same "jokes" over and over if it gets a laugh the first time, etc. Redirecting him to a different activity or even just a different topic of conversation usually helps too. But when it comes down to it, we can't expect to change other people; only our reactions to them. That's something that your 12-year-old is not too young to learn. Good luck.

Posts.Content: kebab wrote: No, this isn't an ill-disguised ploy to get birthday wishes.... it's just me expressing the thoughts rolling in my head to the group of people who can "get it". When I was diagnosed stage iv in April of 2012, my doctor told me median survival was 2 years and I shouldn't expect more time than that. I seriously considered just curling up in a ball and waiting to die. But I didn't. I moved across the continent with my children, got married to a wonderful man and created a new life (with a new medical team!) in California. In the past 3 years I've seen my children grow and blossom, we've made amazing memories and life has been good -- even with chemo and se's thrown in the mix. But it still shocks me, somehow, that I'm 45 years old. I honestly, in some part of my being, never expected to find myself at this birthday milestone. So, as the saying goes (sort of), I've come a long way baby. Let's see just how much further I can go! Stay-at-home mom to 13-yo daughter and 11-yo son. stage iv, node and bone mets; 03/2013 liver mets; 05/2016 brain mets; hospice care. Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2014 09:37PM kebab wrote: If they know it has spread to her bones, then she is now at stage iv, also known as metastatic. Try not to jump to any conclusions and please stay away from google until you have some facts and test results from the doctors. Remember that no one has an expiry date stamped on them and everyone is different. This is going to be a scary time, but once your mom gets started on a treatment program, there's every chance that she will improve. There are stories of women living 10 or 20 years with bone mets. There's no reason that couldn't be your mom's story too. The stage iv forum here has a thread for questions, and there is a good caregivers forum too. You might want to check in there once you have more information. Hang in there.

On a prior visit there, I talked to the Oncology department at his medical group, as well as to the insurance providers. It all sounds really good to me, but I don't know if there are things I'm missing or questions I'm not asking. I don't know what I don't know, you know? Any thoughts? Thanks so much, in advance. Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2014 01:47AM kebab wrote: Vadre -- I would have cheered for your hubby too after that speech! Well done him! Nel... wth. I'm still just shaking my head at that one... I get blood draws every 2 weeks and one of my vials has a STAT designation, which means that I can go to the next available tech after I check in, instead of waiting for my number to be called like everyone else. It's uncomfortable and I always get those "what makes her so special" looks, but so far no one has said anything about it (at least not in my hearing). I'm waiting for the day that someone does complain though. I'll be ready to offer them my spot at the head of the queue -- only if they'll take my stage iv cancer with it though! There's an interesting video that makes the rounds on Facebook occasionally, about the hidden struggles that everyone is dealing with. You just never know what people have on their plate. It would be nice if everyone could just be kind and considerate of others, without needing "proof" of a good reason to do so.

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2014 08:22PM kebab wrote: Not so much a "what people say" story, but I think it sort of fits here anyway. I hope that's ok. I went to a new infusion center today, as I started a clinical trial.¬† They don't have the dreaded "end of chemo" bell there. Oh no. Something so much better. ... a group of nurses sing to the patient having their final treatment, to the tune of "My Boyfriend's Back" (yeah, "You're chemos done and you're gonna get out of here, hey now, hey now..." complete with clapping and a little dance routine). I got to witness the show 3 times during the time I was there today.¬† The first time was was just stunned, the second I was sad, and the third, I just jammed my earbuds in and turned my iPod waaaay up. Sigh.¬† I makes me feel like such a Scrooge or a grump, and I understand that it's a happy occasion for those ending chemo, but really people, can you not do your celebrating at home in private?¬†

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2015 04:07PM kebab wrote: Man... I had to call the advice nurse this weekend. Had chemo on Wednesday and on Friday afternoon I spiked a fever of 101.5. So, lucky me, the nurse that answered my call was a bc survivor (I'll bet she was wearing pink scrubs). She looks at my file and says "ooh, you've had a tough year!" (me, in my head, yeah, actually it's been 3 tough years, but...ok). She: I had breast cancer too you know. Me: Hm. I hope you're doing well now. She: Well it's been 18 years now, so you do the math! Me: (wtf does that even mean?) Uh. Good for you. Congratulations. She: I looked awesome without hair. Totally rocked the look. Me: (still feverish and ill) That's great. She: Let me give you a little advice. No shoes in the house. They bring in germs you know! Me: (speechless... but praising the LORD that after that gem, she finally passed me along to a doctor...) I wish people would understand that all bc paths are not the same and are not comparable. I cut some slack to Jane on the street who probably still doesn't know what mbc is, but a nurse, with all my medical information there in front of her?? She should know better. I feel like instead of getting the medical help I was calling for, I got the opportunity to congratulate yet another survivor on not being me.

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2013 12:04AM kebab wrote: I pushed for the biopsy. I've been on anti-hormonals for a year and had my ovaries out and the mets are still growing and moving. We're treating the mets as hormone-positive based on my original testing from 2008. I'd like the biopsy done to make sure that the type hasn't changed in the meantime. I was surprised by the idea of another scan too - especially since I just had one less than a month ago, but the onc says if it's flaring up in my breast, she wants to know where else it's flaring up too, before we go any further. We'll see what the next week brings.¬† Thanks for listening. :)

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2013 01:59PM kebab wrote: I do agree that as a show of solidarity for a friend or family member, to help them not feel so out of place, it's a nice gesture. I was in the church choir during my first run with chemo and I mentioned to the choir director that I thought I would take a break from choir because I wouldn't feel comfortable at the front of the church the way I looked. He took it to the rest of the choir and they decided, as a group, that if it would make me feel better up there, they would all shave their heads too! I said it wasn't necessary, but it did show me just how much they cared about me feeling comfortable and the lengths they would go to to help me. It was a moment I'll always remember. But, strangers wearing bald caps for charity? That's just stupid. I don't get all the Facebook petitions about the bald Barbie to make little girls feel better either.¬† How does it help, exactly? For me, all it does is remind me of this damn disease, especially in those too brief moments when I may have been able to put it out of my mind.

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2013 12:28PM kebab wrote: I'm sorry to hear about your mom's progression. I think in general, with hormone-positive cancer, the first line of treatment is to move from tamoxifen to the hormone therapies. In my own case, I was on tamoxifen for about 9 months, progressing all the while. Then we tried letrozole/Femara and I progressed on that too, so now I'm onto a chemo. Once things are under control, I'll probably go back to the hormonals again. Hormonals tend to be easier on us, so they are used before jumping to harsher treatments. The first few months after diagnosis are hard, but once there is a treatment plan in place things should get easier. Good luck to you both.

Posts.Content: May 9, 2013 06:10AM kebab wrote: I'm going to just echo what some of the others have said already, but I'll say it anyway. I can deal with dying. That doesn't scare me at all. But what breaks my heart every single day is knowing that I will be leaving my children behind to grow up without me. And being BRCA2+ to boot, means that there is a good chance that one or both of them will also have to fight this battle themselves when they are older, without the support and love of their mother to help them through. I love my kids and can't even imagine my life without them, but if I could turn back time and change one thing, I'm not sure I would ever have brought them into this world if I knew then that this is how my life would play out. I can't bear to think of the hurt that I will cause them and the void that will be left in their lives. Emotions aside, though, I'm lucky that my kids are in school full-time. I can't imagine having to sort out childcare arrangements for every single appointment and treatment. Being a mom is exhausting on its own. Add the cancer exhaustion level to that... whew. I hope you don't feel that I'm lecturing. I just wanted to let you know how it is for me. I hope that you can find the answers that work for you. Sending you strength and peace.

Posts.Content: kebab wrote: I'm frustrated with my stupid leg/lack of mobility. Just venting... I'm only 3 weeks since my stage iv dx. I feel fine. Actually, since starting the Zoladex, I feel better than I have in months. The pain in my neck and between my shoulder blades (that I thought was stress/stiff muscles/tension, but turned out to be neck/spine mets) is gone. For the first time since Christmas, I can look over my shoulder!¬† But my left hip/leg has gone dowhill, fast.¬† I'm suddenly walking with a cane, at age 40! What kind of crap is this? If I didn't have people constantly asking about the cane/my limp, I wouldn't have to explain my health at all. I'm on oxycodone and gabapentin, and sometimes get relief if I take 1 pill of each, both at the same time. More than 100 mg at a time of gabapentin makes my leg muscles seize up completely and I can barely move. More than 1 oxy just makes me too stoned to function. But the 2 together seems to loosen something up and give me a bit easier mobility for a short time. I complained enough to my onc. and he set me up with radiation. I got one shot to my left femur on Thursday and I am scheduled for a shot to the back of the hip this week. No change yet from the first zap though.¬† I really have a feeling it's more like something pinched in my low back that is causing the problem. If I concentrate and go slowly, I can put my leg/hip through a full range of motion. The muscles are tight, but the will move. I just can't put any weight on it. Stepping onto my left leg sends pain down into my knee and sometimes my ankle. I can stand on both feet with no pain and no trouble, but if I lift my right foot off the floor, I fall over to the left. No balance at all. And sometimes when I step with my left foot, even with the cane, my hip just sort of "buckles" and I stumble. I'm really glad my doctors are so eager to fight my "pain" with drugs and rads, but I can't get them to understand that this isn't so much a pain issue... I don't know where else to turn.¬† Normally, I would head to my chiropractor, but he "fired" me after learning I have spine mets. Doesn't want to "mess" with that. Physiotherapy? Acupuncture? I'm terrified to try anything not suggested by my onc, for fear of messing things up more than they already are. Anybody ever have issues like this? Or suggestions of what to try next? I can get my head around this diagnosis but I cannot get my head around walking with a cane for the rest of whatever time I have left. Not acceptable! Stay-at-home mom to 13-yo daughter and 11-yo son. stage iv, node and bone mets; 03/2013 liver mets; 05/2016 brain mets; hospice care. Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2012 05:01PM kebab wrote: Try not to freak out until you know for sure what you are dealing with.¬† If it is in the breast and the lymph nodes near the breast/under arm, that's not metastatic. If the affected lymph nodes are in another part of your body, and/or there is cancer in your organs or bones, then it would be considered metastatic, and metastatic = stage IV. Do not try to diagnose yourself and really, really stay away from Google. There is so much misinformation floating around out there, all it will do is upset you more.¬† Try to stay calm until you see the oncologist and he/she can give you some real answers. I hope that you can get an appointment soon. You'll find lots of support here in the meantime.

Posts.Content: kebab wrote: I posted this in the "finances" section of the boards but didn't get any responses. Sorry for the repost, but hopefully someone here will have something to say. I have learned that my fiance's health care plan, which will cover me for any treatment I need, doesn't cover any "end of life" care. No in-home care, etc. It covers hospice, but there are limited beds available and it's in a city 60 miles from our home. The numbers he got were that out of pocket, in-home care would likely run about $5-6K per month. I am hoping that this is a long way off for me (for all of us!), but I'm a planning kind of girl. I need to know how things are going to go. So, I'm wondering if this lack of insurance coverage is normal in the US or how other people deal with this stuff. I know that there is long-term insurance, but with already having a stage IV dx, I'd guess it's a bit late to get onboard with that. What do people do when it comes to end of life care? Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2014 10:53AM kebab wrote: Interesting discussion! I see several posts that use the term remission where I would use regression instead. I thought regression was tumors shrinking. NED and remission I would use interchangeably for no measurable cancer activity anywhere.¬† Honestly, I just can't use the word "cure" for breast cancer. I think people get good long periods of NED/remission, but once it's in the body it's just too easy for it to lie dormant for a while and then rear its ugly head again sometime down the road.¬† There is no cure for breast cancer. I cringe every time I hear someone say they are cured -- not because I'm not happy for them. I certainly am! -- but because that is the word that their listeners latch onto and then expect all of us to be cured... and then we're not... and somehow it's our own fault (didn't eat enough lemons and baking soda maybe?), because they know so-and-so who had breast cancer and was "cured".¬† People (perhaps the one originally mentioned in this thread) who state that they have survived (past tense) stage iv breast cancer make me cringe for the same reason. I'm certainly happy for them, but their words just seem to make it that much harder for the rest of us to make the reality of our situation understood. Anyway, that's my 2 cents.

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2014 10:58PM kebab wrote: Waaaay back in the 80s, I read an article that said that antiperspirants caused cancer, so I asked my doctor about it. He said that people are either "wired" to get cancer or they are not. Those wired for it will be triggered somehow, by something, and those not wired for it can be exposed to the same triggers and be just fine. That makes sense to me. Partially genetic and partially environmental. But those of us "wired" for it can't spend our lives living in a bubble, can we? There are just sooooo many possible triggers, it boggles the mind -- the food we eat, water we drink, air we breathe, clothing we wear, etc. I go back to my "crap shoot" theory.

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2015 12:55PM kebab wrote: I do neupogen shots for 6 days after each chemo infusion and I was almost crippled by the pain on those days for several cycles. Taking 1 claritin a day didn't help much, but a few cycles ago the resident doctor suggested taking 1 in the morning and 1 in the evening, starting 3 days before the first neupogen shot and continuing until the day after the last shot. The change has been amazing. I still need to take pain killers to sleep at night, but the pain is lessened to an irritating ache instead of the all encompassing agony I had been in before. I am a firm believer in claritin. I don't know why it works, but it does! I'm glad you've found something that helps you!
Posts.Title: Hit by a Train AmyQ AmyQ

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2016 05:21PM kebab wrote: I've got a stent on the right side. I've had it for just over 2 months now. I have a lymph node pressing on the ureter and not letting the kidney drain and my kidney was heading for failure. Within 2 days of getting the stent, my kidney function was back to normal. I have what is called a nephroureteral stent. That means I have a tube hanging out of my back that can connect to a bag in case of a problem with the stent, but is usually just capped and taped to my back. The internal stent goes from my kidney, through the ureter, and into my bladder, so I can urinate normally. It's been okay. The stent has to be changed every 8 weeks or so and I have to go to the hospital every 2 weeks to have the dressings on my back changed by the nurse. Let me know if you have any specific questions and I'll do my best to answer from my experience.

Amy R, having gone thru BMX and chemo, should know by now. It has nothing to do with toughness or fighting hard enough, even at early stages. We do what the doctors tell us, or we die. That's it. That's just doing what we have to do.¬† I don't begrudge her feeling good (I'm jealous, but I don't begrudge her).¬† I guess I just hoped that she would finally be the one to tell a different side of the story... and she let me down.

Posts.Content: May 25, 2012 08:55AM - edited May 25, 2012 08:56AM by kebab I had neupogen during my original chemo -- 10 days of shots and 4 days of rest, for 8 cycles. I would recommend letting it come to room temp or at least taking it out of the refrigerator for even 15-20 minutes before. When it's cold, you feel it going in. Not that it's painful, but why make it any more unpleasant than it needs to be? I don't know how long you'll be on it, but for me the effects were cumulative -- barely any side effects from the first set of shots, but increasing pain in my thigh bones with each cycle. By cycle 8, I could barely walk without feeling like my femurs were going to snap... but on the positive side, after a couple of my "rest" days had passed, the SEs subsided each time. Within a week of finishing the last cycle, the bone pain was completely gone. I can't remember any other side effects specifically.¬† Hope that helps.

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2015 06:43PM kebab wrote: I'm on carboplatin with taxol. I can't speak to side effects because I really don't know which are from what drug. I can share with you something that I found out at my infusion last week. With carboplatin, they start to watch for allergic-reaction types of symptoms after about the 7th infusion. Normally it will infuse over 30 minutes, but after the 7th infusion it should be reduced to go in over 2 or more hours, to try to reduce the possibility of a reaction. (I just had my 11th infusion pumped in over 30 minutes. When I said I was suddenly hot and had itchy hands and feet, THEN I learned about the possibility of reaction... not impressed...) Good luck with it! I hope you have no troubles at all.

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2015 11:32AM kebab wrote: I'm in the waiting room this week. I've done 19 cycles on the clinical trial and it's scan time (every 3 cycles). My TMs are up just a smidge but are still half of what they were when I started the trial, so I'm going to look at that as positive news. The reports from the bone and CT scans arrived in my inbox within 24 hours and seemed to say (to my eyes at least) that all is still stable, aside from "mass in rt breast 2.8 x 1.8 x 2.7 cm (previous measurement 2.6 x 1.5 x 2.1 cm)". This is the same mass that I was blissfully ignoring for an entire year (while in tx for stage iv) because it didn't show up on my PET scans and my regular onc was assuring me was nothing to worry about. I got on the trial, it shows up on CT, and suddenly we're calling it a tumor. Sigh. Anyway, the trial onc has asked to review the actual scans herself this time so I'm delivering the CD to her today. I think I'm allowed a 30% progression from baseline to remain in the trial. Fingers are Firmly crossed that it's less than that and I can continue. Thanks for being here, hanging out in the waiting room and sharing your support. I can't tell my friends or family how scared I am, but you all just get it. I appreciate all of you!

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2014 10:26PM kebab wrote: I don't know how similar taxol is to taxotere but since they're both taxoids, I'll chime in. I've done 5 3-week cycles of taxol and carboplatin so far. They told me it would be a "cake walk" compared to TAC, but I haven't found it easy at all. It has seriously knocked me on my butt every cycle.¬†¬† I get chemo on day 3 of my cycle. Day 4 is usually good except for fatigue. I am crippled by leg pain on days 5 through 7 and spend most of that time knocked out on oxycodone. Day 8 the diarrhea usually hits. By day 12, I start to feel human again and then gradually get a bit better and a bit less fatigued each day, until the next cycle starts, so 1 good week out of every 3. Twice so far I've had to have a cycle delayed for a week to let my platelets regroup.¬†¬† This is part of a clinical trial for me and they say I can go up to 2 years on it. My regular onc (not involved in the trial) said she would have never put me on this combo and wouldn't expect that my body could handle more than about 6 cycles.¬† ...we'll see, I guess. Hang in there. The 2nd week is better than the first, and by the 3rd week you'll be feeling pretty good. It's just hellish getting through that first week.

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2014 08:30PM - edited Jun 11, 2014 08:33PM by kebab Welcome to the forums. :) I think Peterborough has a fairly decent oncology department. When I was doing my ATC chemo, I went on vacation in that area and my own onc was very happy that I'd be near the Peterborough hospital should anything go wrong while I was away from home, as he was confident they could take good care of me. Also, you are going to be spending a lot of time at the hospital while you are in treatment. For me, I was at the hospital at least 2 days every 2 weeks. You are going to feel crappy and be tired. That 2 hour drive between Peterborough and Toronto is going to become miserable really, really fast. That's just my opinion though. You need to do what feels right to you, and we will support you in your decision. As for the possibility of the spot on your spine, try not to worry until you know for sure that there is something to worry about. You have enough on your plate just now. You don't need to think about the what-ifs until you get more information. Sending you strength. hrm. edited to add: It may seem out of left field that I'm talking about Peterborough but my profile says California.... I lived in the Kitchener/Waterloo area when I was first diagnosed and treated.

It scares the crap out of me that even with both drugs, the cancer is still fighting back so hard.¬† I don't know yet if this means I'll be kicked off the trial or if they'll let me try another 3 cycles. They're waiting to find out her hormone and her2 status before they decide whether she'll get chemo or not. A little good news would go really nicely today. Thanks for listening. Stay-at-home mom to 13-yo daughter and 11-yo son. stage iv, node and bone mets; 03/2013 liver mets; 05/2016 brain mets; hospice care. I am so thankful. I'm still just getting used to this treatment and am so not ready to change things up yet.¬† Whew. How do I spell relief?¬†¬† S-t-a-b-l-e.¬† :)
Posts.Title: Well dang it... kebab WinningSoFar

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2012 04:32PM kebab wrote: I worry too about the end, when I'm not able to care for my kids any longer.¬† My fiance is great and I hope for several more years - time for he and the kids to really gel and become family, plus time for the kids to get a bit older (they are 7 & 10 now).¬† It would destroy me to have to send them away to live with their father before I'm gone. I'm hoping that either my mom or my sister will be able to come and stay with us right at the end, so the kids can be with me til the end. I try not to think about it too much. There are too many what ifs involved. I think the craziest part of the disease is knowing we are going to die too soon, but not knowing if it might be 6 months or 6 years down the line. It throws a real wrench in the ability to plan anything. I just do my best to enjoy today and make it the best it can be.¬† I think the hardest part for me is knowing I'm BRCA2 pos and wondering every day if I've passed this mess on to my kids. I can't bear to think of my daughter or son going through this without their mom.

Posts.Title: "Awareness" rant! kayrnic AmyJM

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2014 02:58PM kebab wrote: I was diagnosed with liver mets almost 18 months ago. It really set me back, mentally and emotionally. I thought it was the beginning of the end and I cried for weeks. And then I started on oral chemo (Xeloda) and within a few months, the liver mets had disappeared. If Xeloda is what you will be on, check out the All about Xeloda thread here. Tons of tips in there for dealing with the various side effects. But the good news is that Xeloda is pretty well tolerated and does really great work for a lot of people.¬† I ended my time on Xeloda after about a year and my liver mets came back, but so far, I'm not sick and jaundiced and weak and all the other things I thought would go along with liver mets. If I didn't know I had liver mets, I wouldn't know they were there... does that even make sense? Hang in there. Getting your head around the diagnosis is the hardest part, in my experience.
